ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I think the most important thing I learned in this course, that I will continue to use, was how to do dynamic programming, and how to adapt that to various different models.
computational methods

A peek into how common numerical algorithms work in practice, including numerical derivatives, root-solvers, integral simulation, and others. A focus on dynamic programming problems from macroeconomics. Not much in the way of proofs if that's what you're looking for.
Methods to solve economics problems, such as dynamic programming and value function iteration.
Numerical methods
Numerical methods
Learned how to use various methods of root-finding, finding maxima, and solving dynamic program problems. One of the best courses if you want to learn how structural models are actually solved!
Dynamic programming, root finding, other computational methods and their applications to various areas in economics, including climate models and human capital development. Learned how to use Julia.
I learned about various coding techniques, such as root-finding and VFI methods.
Julia coding, bellman equations, dynamic programming
Various numeric analysis algorithms (Newtons method, Brents method, DP, etc)

I learned how to use the julia programming language and how to code various problems from microeconomics and macroeconomics. The course also helped me to improve my foundations in macroeconomics and microeconomics.

I learned about numerical methods (root-finding, optimization, integration, differentiation, function approximation, interpolation) and how to apply them to solve macroeconomic models (neoclassical growth, stochastic growth, Aiyagari) as well as other interesting applications (options pricing, carbon tax)
Various advanced numerical methods and how they could be implemented in Julia as well as be used to solve a variety of economic problems
I learned how to code in Julia and basic dynamic programming methods.
I learned how to code in Julia, many numerical methods, and various economic models.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strengths are that the problem sets were very good, as well as Professor Smith's lectures.
all good
There was a lot of interesting content with regards to using math to solve economics models, but sometimes the different topics felt a little disjointed.

As a graduate student, it felt like much of it was review, especially with the applications covered. Knowing which lectures would cover graduate level material would have kept the course more engaging.
Second half of the material is not very useful since we are not graded on it. I would have preferred a few problems sets on that material as well!

The lectures are a little disorganized. Other than that, the homework scaffolds really nicely and helps drive home the key concepts in computational methods. I feel like I have a codebase that I can actually apply to my other work.

This course is excellent. The lectures are engaging, the problem sets are doable and helped me better understand the material, and the final project was a great way to practice the methods I had learned and to learn more about a subfield of econ that I am interested in. I can't really think of any ways to improve.

I think the topics covered are interesting and useful, and I appreciate how the problem sets are designed so that we can try applying the technique to an actual problem. I think that the course could be more effective if there were different sections for undergrads/graduate students with techniques and applications more targeted to each student group.

Tony is a fantastic professor. TA section was also very helpful. The course would be improved with more engagement in the second half of the course - without the psets it was hard to feel like I was grasping the material.
Project was fun to work in, homework very manageable, not always the most engaging
The strengths of this course were in the problem sets which were challenging but helped me to think about how to computationally represent recurring problems in microeconomics and macroeconomics.

The psets are so good and the organization of the course fully exposed me to what economic models look like! I think the classroom instruction could be made more effective by a more linear progression of topics. Also, some of the content feels very wishy washy.

Strengths: the course covers a wide breadth of numerical methods that can be used to solve so many different economic problems, well-defined course structure, flexibility and freedom on the final project, which allowed me to focus on a topic I found interesting and make a cool project out of it.

Weaknesses: because so many topics were covered, we didn't receive many examples applying the topics we used, so when tested on those methods in the problem sets, a challenge was turning the theory and explanation into something more tangible to provide a problem set solution, very quick turnaround time on learning challenging topics within Julia to implement complicated principles

The problem sets were very helpful in understanding the material, but it is a little daunting with so many different skill levels in the class. Also, (and I think Prof Smith is going to improve this) the high level material at the end of the semester was difficult to grasp without any applications. Also, it is hard to know what grade you will get because most of it is the final project. Again, the level of skill for a senior who can use thesis research or a phd student will be much higher than a student without economics research experience.
The first half of the course is very useful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to others, it can open a lot of doors for senior essay work, or to study different models that interest you in economics. It really gives you a lot of important tools to build on.
Sure
Yes, it was a good introduction to a lot of different problem-solving methods.
Absolutely if you're interested in graduate economics. Otherwise, it might not be that relevant for you.

Yes, certainly. The course is taught well and Professor Smith is a very clear lecturer. The material helped me begin to understand what goes on behind the scenes in econ papers that postulate a structural model of the world and use methods to estimate various components of the model.
The course is a great introduction to Julia, and it provides ample opportunities to practice various coding techniques.
Absolutely, take this class!
If youre interested in Econ research, yes
I would recommend this course to economics students who wish to have an intensive learning experience in numerical analysis.
Yes! I would recommend it to any econ major (especially juniors who want to write a thesis) with an interest in learning about how to solve more advanced economic models.

I think I'd recommend this course to a student if they could fulfill part of their major using it. It fulfills the joint CS-Econ credit needed for the CS-Econ major and honestly offers a pretty interesting way to complete that requirement. That being said, I'd only recommend it to someone who is comfortable with advanced mathematical notation and ideally has programming experience. I'd definitely recommend that the student has actually completed the prerequisites for this course to allow them to get the most out of it because the material does get pretty challenging.

I would because it could be helpful for your senior thesis. That being said, if you take it before you are a senior, it may be stressful without experience with research in Economics. I am stressed about my grade just because I did not have the skills other students did to apply to the final project.
Yes
